mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Federal-funding mechanisms represent an often-underused funding source for public- and private-sector stakeholders when enhancing SDoH data, analytics, and technology infrastructure.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fhealthcare%20systems%20and%20services%2Four%20insights%2Ffederal%20funding%20may%20boost%20social%20determinants%20of%20health%20infrastructure%2Ffederal-funding-may-boost-social-determinants-of-health-infrastructure.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="federal-funding-may-boost-social-determinants-of-health-infrastructure" data-layer-report-name="federal-funding-may-boost-social-determinants-of-health-infrastructure>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (14 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Social determinants of health (SDoH)</strong>—the conditions in which people live and the systems that shape those conditions—are increasingly receiving attention. The COVID-19 pandemic, by exacerbating inequities and highlighting the prevalence of unmet basic needs,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="60419cef-711d-43ef-975b-78b1939dff2c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="60419cef-711d-43ef-975b-78b1939dff2c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Patrick Drake and Robin Rudowitz, “Tracking social determinants of health during the COVID-19 pandemic,” Kaiser Family Foundation, April 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> has accelerated efforts to address SDoH.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="74b7d886-f56d-4275-8497-3225faf39164"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="74b7d886-f56d-4275-8497-3225faf39164" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has announced health equity is a strategic priority, the US Department for Health and Human Services (HHS) has prioritized strengthening equitable access to care and strengthening social well-being, and the Biden administration is focusing on health equity and complementary data capacity, such as through the Executive Order on Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities.</span></span></span></a></span> State Medicaid agencies, payers, providers, vendors, community-based organizations (CBOs), and other stakeholders have taken up the torch and are laying the foundations for long-term SDoH programs (see sidebar “What are social determinants of health?”).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Fadesola Adetosoye, <a href="/our-people/tamara-baer">Tamara Baer</a>, <a href="/our-people/jessica-kahn">Jessica Kahn</a>, Savannah Leonard, and Alex Mandel, representing views from McKinsey’s Healthcare Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Despite the momentum, however, many stakeholders across the ecosystem are still in the early stages of addressing patients’ SDoH sustainably and at scale. Stakeholders largely cite funding as the largest barrier to real progress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cff196ae-d9f7-4f99-b787-407b67908349"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cff196ae-d9f7-4f99-b787-407b67908349" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Addressing social determinants of health via Medicaid managed care contracts and section 1115 demonstrations,” Association for Community Affiliated Plans, December 2018; Kim Nichols Dauner and Lacey Loomer, “A qualitative assessment of barriers and facilitators associated with addressing social determinants of health among members of a health collaborative in the rural Midwest,” <em>BMC Health Services Research</em>, 2021, Volume 21; Emily Sokol, “Financial incentives biggest barrier to social determinants of health,” RevCycleIntelligence, November 16, 2022; McKinsey Provider SDoH survey, December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Many stakeholders know of available funding for delivering services such as food assistance, housing support, and transportation. However, options for funding data, analytics, and technology infrastructure that can optimize efforts to deliver services are less well-known. But this funding does indeed exist. And it can be used to support data integration (collating social-needs data alongside clinical and other data) and screening and referral capabilities (business processes and capabilities that include SDoH data sets to drive enrollment into targeted case management profiles for patients’ risk profile).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What are social determinants of health?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>This paper uses</strong> two phrases throughout: “unmet basic needs” and “social determinants of health” (SDoH). We define unmet basic needs as the lack of a basic resource such as food, safe housing, or transportation. An unmet basic need may or may not have an adverse effect on a person’s health. SDoH is used to refer to the nonmedical factors that influence health outcomes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2fcca640-7600-4e20-905c-371c136073b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2fcca640-7600-4e20-905c-371c136073b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Social determinants of health,” World Health Organization (WHO).</span></span></span></a></span> The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines SDoH as the conditions in the environments where people are born, live, learn, work, play, and age that affect a wide range of health risks and outcomes. Examples include education access and quality, neighborhoods and built environments, and economic stability.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="534450f1-21ed-4da8-966e-d881f1d0fa65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="534450f1-21ed-4da8-966e-d881f1d0fa65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Social determinants of health,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), last reviewed March 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Studies indicate that approximately 20 percent of an individual’s health is related to clinical care. Nonclinical factors, including SDoH, are responsible for the remaining 80 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f5364d7a-1321-4d54-a2ae-34c68e555b13"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f5364d7a-1321-4d54-a2ae-34c68e555b13" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>2020 county health rankings key findings report</em>, Country Health Ranking & Roadmaps, March 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Across the healthcare industry, stakeholders are increasingly recognizing that addressing SDoH, which reflect unmet basic needs, can lead to improved health outcomes and better quality and costs of care.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1004c0f-f952-4f65-9edf-52bccb094eab"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1004c0f-f952-4f65-9edf-52bccb094eab" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Review of evidence for health-related social needs interventions,” The Commonwealth Fund, July 2019; “Addressing social determinants of health: Examples of successful evidence-based strategies and current federal efforts,” Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, April 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Other common terms include “social risk factors” or “social influencers of health.” Language is increasingly evolving to recognize that social factors are influences on (rather than determinants of) health and well-being.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>In pursuing these programs and seeking to secure funding, coordination across stakeholders may be crucial. SDoH is cut across a variety of focus areas and could be addressed better by working across payers, providers, states, communities, and other local actors and agencies. SDoH vendors can work alongside states and other entities to identify these funding possibilities and unify disparate stakeholders to unlock financial assistance, potentially resulting in evidence-based solutions across systems, clinical departments, and programs—and, ultimately, increased impact (see sidebar “Federal funding opportunities for actors that address social determinants of health”).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Federal funding opportunities for actors that address social determinants of health</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>State Medicaid agencies:</strong> These agencies support the administration and operation of the Medicaid program in their states and determine coverage for social determinants of health (SDoH) support. They also develop the data and infrastructure necessary to identify and address people’s SDoH-related needs. These agencies are primary recipients of federal funding through mechanisms such as waivers and authorities. They can also partner with vendors, community partners, or providers to access new funding and allocate acquired capital—for example, using funding from a Section 1115 waiver to partner on closed-loop referrals.</p>

<p><strong>SDoH vendors:</strong> Vendors are typically private organizations that contract with other actors to support SDoH service delivery or data and infrastructure. They can receive funding indirectly through partnerships and contracting, such as through work with state Medicaid agencies, managed-care organizations, or state health information exchanges.</p>

<p><strong>Payers:</strong> These organizations cover members’ medical costs and can work alongside providers to ensure members’ health needs (including SDoH-related needs) are met. Funding can come through subcontracts with states on provision of services to beneficiaries.</p>

<p><strong>Providers:</strong> Providers consist of physicians and other practitioners who provide direct care to patients, screen for unmet basic needs, provide referrals to support, and at times offer direct-service provisions (for example, a hospital offering food support). Federal funding can come indirectly through partnerships and subcontracting, such as risk-based payment models.</p>

<p><strong>Community-based organizations (CBOs):</strong> These not-for-profit organizations primarily provide relief to the community—for example, through food banks and housing organizations. They can provide direct services for individuals with SDoH-related needs and may also support other actors with local knowledge and credibility. They may receive federal funding indirectly through grant programs, or they can receive additional funding through partnerships such as a managed-care organization referral partnership.</p>

<p><strong>Other state and local agencies:</strong> These departments and agencies include counties, cities, behavioral-health facilities, and aging organizations. They help allocate resources to CBOs and other entities to address unmet basic needs. These groups are primary recipients of federal funding for select financing mechanisms, such as grants from national entities such as the CDC and through recent legislation such as the American Rescue Plan Act, which provided $350 billion to state, local, and other entities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="11b7565a-ac85-4cef-91d0-3a31408be80d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="11b7565a-ac85-4cef-91d0-3a31408be80d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Assistance for state, local, and tribal governments,” US Department of the Treasury.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>This article describes four federal financing mechanisms that are available to support SDoH data and analytics efforts and considerations for accessing them. While these insights primarily focus on possibilities for state Medicaid agencies, there are implications and potential opportunities for stakeholders across the ecosystem. This analysis is not exhaustive; rather, it provides a helpful starting point for planning and forming partnerships to support SDoH.</p>

<h2>Four federal-funding channels are available for SDoH infrastructure efforts</h2>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Definitions of funding terms</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Federal match:</strong> A federal match is the share the federal government will contribute to a project based on the nonfederal share of costs the grantee is contributing to the effort. In Medicaid, there are two common types of federal matches:</p>

<ul>
    <li><em>Federal Medical-Assistance Percentage (FMAP).</em> For every dollar the state spends on Medicaid, the federal government matches at a rate that varies from year to year. FMAP is the portion paid by the federal government to states for their share of expenditures for providing Medicaid services as well as administering the Medicaid program and other human service programs. It is computed from a formula that considers the average per capita income for each state relative to the national average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fc197524-a8b0-4984-847b-70efab78db98"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fc197524-a8b0-4984-847b-70efab78db98" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Medicaid’s federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP),” Congressional Research Service, July 29, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Federal Financial Participation (FFP).</em> FFP is the share of each state’s Medicaid administrative costs paid by the federal government (that is, matching funds for states’ systems and data infrastructure expenditures, often at an enhanced match rate of 75 to 90 percent).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e7cd0bf-8cfb-4be7-81a1-fc8b4433cea4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e7cd0bf-8cfb-4be7-81a1-fc8b4433cea4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Federal match rates for Medicaid administrative activities,” Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC).</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Medicaid waivers and authorities:</strong> Under a Medicaid waiver or authority, a state can waive certain Medicaid eligibility requirements and expand offered services, covering care for people who might not otherwise be eligible (for example, waiving Section 1115 of Title XIX of the Social Security Act).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2200fd15-ef78-4302-bafa-3f9ba9b9651a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2200fd15-ef78-4302-bafa-3f9ba9b9651a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Waivers,” MACPAC.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p><strong>Medical loss ratio (MLR):</strong> An MLR is the proportion of a premium a health plan spends on healthcare claims and quality improvement activities compared with administrative activities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e875a938-0d0f-4c36-941e-7be6b5dbab49"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e875a938-0d0f-4c36-941e-7be6b5dbab49" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Social determinants of health: Data sharing at the community level,” Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, March 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Stakeholders can consider four federal-funding channels to advance their SDoH goals: waivers and authorities, federal agencies and programs, emerging opportunities resulting from recent legislation, and managed-care standards and support. Some of these federal channels provide ongoing support, for example, through a federal match or reimbursement strategy, while others provide one-time support such as through grants (see sidebar “Definitions of funding terms”). Local- or state-level and private or philanthropic funding, while not evaluated in this article, may provide additional funding opportunities for stakeholders to consider.</p>

<h3>1. Waivers and authorities</h3>

<p>Although federal Medicaid funds are traditionally used to cover the costs of medical services, a variety of waivers and authorities have added flexibility so these funds can cover nonmedical services outside of the Medicaid state plan—such as case management, food support, and housing support—that contribute to health outcomes (Exhibit 1). This added flexibility may also cover data and analytics infrastructure to help improve how SDoH services are delivered and the outcomes of these services on people’s lives.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cc93f467-02ef-4d6b-8c13-9d300fdc74e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cc93f467-02ef-4d6b-8c13-9d300fdc74e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Elizabeth Hinton and Lina Stolyar, “Medicaid authorities and options to address social determinants of health (SDOH),” Kaiser Family Foundation, August 5, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) articulated a number of these waivers, authorities, and other supports available to address SDoH in a letter to state health officials in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce5e1868-8f2b-4d96-b92a-2dd39505080f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce5e1868-8f2b-4d96-b92a-2dd39505080f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Opportunities in Medicaid & CHIP to address SDoH</em>, CMS, January 7, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> More recently, the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC) released an issue brief on SDoH financing strategies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c19d49c2-b7f7-4a64-97c3-574fed97a5e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c19d49c2-b7f7-4a64-97c3-574fed97a5e0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Financing Strategies to Address the Social Determinants of Health in Medicaid,” Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC), May 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>How California and North Carolina have harnessed waivers to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>California and North Carolina</strong> provide examples of how states can harness waivers in combination with other funding sources (federal and otherwise) to advance social determinants of health (SDoH) service delivery and data and technology infrastructure across their Medicaid programs and beyond.</p>

<p>California is working to transform its Medicaid program (known as Medi-Cal) into a whole-person approach through the California Advancing and Innovating Medi-Cal (CalAIM) effort. The California Department of Health Care Services launched CalAIM in January 2022 to improve health outcomes and health equity across the state.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="98319098-6fa6-4c8c-a0a9-59cb62643104"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="98319098-6fa6-4c8c-a0a9-59cb62643104" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CalAIM explained: Overview of new programs and key changes,” California Health Care Foundation, October 26, 2021; “CalAIM Initiative and programs,” Partnership Healthplan of California; Elizabeth Hinton and Michelle Tong, “California efforts to address behavioral health and SDOH: A look at whole person care pilots,” Kaiser Family Foundation, March 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> CalAIM envisions enhanced information exchange, coordination, and data integration across managed-care plans; county agencies; and physical-health, behavioral-health, community-based, and social-service providers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be0901dc-00af-4bac-b713-d7a4e06b66bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be0901dc-00af-4bac-b713-d7a4e06b66bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CalAIM and health data sharing: A road map for effective implementation of enhanced care management and in lieu of services,” California Health Care Foundation, May 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The effort is supported by state funding in addition to several federal authorities, including 1115 and 1915(b) waivers, state plan amendments, and managed-care contracts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b3800770-a5e2-4254-82a6-866df3da5310"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b3800770-a5e2-4254-82a6-866df3da5310" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Updates on the CalAIM Section 1115 & Section 1915(b) waivers,” California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS), January 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The 1115 waiver is particularly relevant for SDoH technology, providing $1.4 billion over five years for an initiative aimed at capacity building, technical assistance, and other efforts, including closed-loop referrals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eb07b1f9-3828-43be-8476-03ca5c421cd1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eb07b1f9-3828-43be-8476-03ca5c421cd1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CalAIM explained,” October 26, 2021; Elizabeth Hinton and Michelle Tong, “California efforts to address,” March 17, 2022; “Updates on the CalAIM,” January 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> To advance closed-loops referrals, CalAIM provides guidance for information sharing, standards to ensure platforms are accessible to contracted providers, and training and technical assistance to support providers in workflow changes and access.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4d756f2-4161-4ff1-af7d-c5b957450ccf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4d756f2-4161-4ff1-af7d-c5b957450ccf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CalAIM and health data sharing,” May 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>North Carolina, meanwhile, is advancing on multiple SDoH-related fronts<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f58f79d-8364-4e48-afe5-57739bb917ff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f58f79d-8364-4e48-afe5-57739bb917ff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Clarissa Donnelly-DeRoven, “‘It’s never been done before’: How NC plans to use Medicaid dollars to improve social determinants of health,” North Carolina Health News, March 9, 2022; “How North Carolina is using Medicaid to address social determinants of health,” Center for American Progress (CAP), February 3, 2022</span></span></span></a></span>:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>NCCARE360.</em> North Carolina developed NCCARE360, a statewide coordinated-care network to better connect individuals to local services and resources.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71223557-d8fc-4aba-ba87-d196be91e9b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71223557-d8fc-4aba-ba87-d196be91e9b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Building connections for a healthier North Carolina,” NCCARE360.</span></span></span></a></span> The NCCARE360 network uses a statewide closed-loop referral platform adopted by state agencies, health systems, community-based organizations (CBOs), and managed-care organizations (MCOs). It began with a public–private partnership between the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (NC DHHS), a foundation, an SDoH technology vendor, and United Way (a not-for-profit driving 211 resource directories).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3aadb4e3-ba83-4495-8447-18bb45e26c98"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3aadb4e3-ba83-4495-8447-18bb45e26c98" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“About NCCARE360,” NCCARE360.</span></span></span></a></span> Initial funding for the network came through the combination of private philanthropy and a Medicaid federal match. NCCARE360 has been expanded and continued by requiring and covering access for Medicaid MCOs and health systems to use the platform for an initial period.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b61bf5a6-574c-47c2-b1a4-2b36716c37f1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b61bf5a6-574c-47c2-b1a4-2b36716c37f1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“A playbook to coordinate care across an entire state,” Unite US; Mandy Krauthamer Cohen, Elizabeth Cuervo Tilson, and Zachary Wortman, “Buying health for North Carolinians: Addressing nonmedical drivers of health at scale,” <em>Health Affairs</em>, 2020, Volume 39, Issue 4; “How North Carolina is using Medicaid,” February 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
<li><em>Healthy Opportunities Pilots.</em> Alongside NCCARE360, North Carolina has been driving SDoH impact through its Healthy Opportunities Pilots.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6c618b3-cf3d-48da-9fdc-ac1f27c702c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6c618b3-cf3d-48da-9fdc-ac1f27c702c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Healthy opportunities pilots,” NCDHHS, last updated August 24, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The pilots aim to both address unmet basic needs for members and build capacity for entities delivering social services, including connecting Medicaid members to reimbursable social-care services, streamlining eligibility and authorization processes, enabling CBOs to automatically invoice for services, and providing data to evaluate outcomes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="885721a2-99c0-43db-b12d-ad02e6bfbb9e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="885721a2-99c0-43db-b12d-ad02e6bfbb9e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Healthy opportunities pilots,” NCDHHS, last updated August 24, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> As a part of this effort, North Carolina has created standard screening questions for unmet basic needs and encourages providers to use NCCARE360.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="becb94c0-11d1-47d3-8d0e-afa31d891908"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="becb94c0-11d1-47d3-8d0e-afa31d891908" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How North Carolina is using Medicaid,” February 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The pilots started through an 1115 waiver that was approved as part of the state’s waiver to transition to Medicaid managed care.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf67bf90-9e08-403d-abd7-b9bda22cf886"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf67bf90-9e08-403d-abd7-b9bda22cf886" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“A playbook to coordinate,” United US; “‘It’s never been done before,” March 9, 2022; “Healthy opportunities pilots,” NCDHHS, last updated August 24, 2022; “How North Carolina is using Medicaid,” February 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Through the waiver, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) granted $650 million in funding over five years, $100 million of which can be used for capacity building with a 50-50 federal match.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="37bcd6c7-57d6-40f5-9c53-9fb56561f2f3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="37bcd6c7-57d6-40f5-9c53-9fb56561f2f3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“A playbook to coordinate,” United US; “‘It’s never been done before,” March 9, 2022; “Healthy opportunities pilots,” NCDHHS, last updated August 24, 2022; “How North Carolina is using Medicaid,” February 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In this transition, North Carolina is advancing SDoH in four ways: having SDoH-related contract requirements, supporting CBOs delivering Healthy Opportunities Pilots’ services, allowing plans to include SDoH service and infrastructure in the numerator of their medical loss ratios (MLRs), and requiring plans to participate in pilots.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e626c0bf-8e83-444f-9bff-6f6e7227b0dc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e626c0bf-8e83-444f-9bff-6f6e7227b0dc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How North Carolina is using Medicaid,” February 3, 2022; “North Carolina Medicaid transformation: Healthy opportunities in Medicaid managed care,” Piedmont Triad Regional Council, June 27, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<p>Both the North Carolina and California case studies demonstrate how states have used waivers alongside other sources to advance their SDoH technology efforts. While North Carolina has approached SDoH technology and closed-loop referral development through a single, state-supported network and platform, California is taking a different approach: supporting data-sharing standards and technical assistance across groups rather than through a single platform or network. These cases reflect the flexibility in how states could use waivers, third-party vendors, and other funding to develop and support SDoH infrastructure.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>While waivers and authorities primarily fund direct-service delivery authorities, states often have flexibility in the proposals they put forth through waivers—for example, they may define their own demonstration project or pilot for an 1115 waiver. But waivers also often include guidelines—such as demanding budget neutrality or that a project demonstrates value in terms of quality and cost to the Medicaid program—to ensure consistency in desired outcomes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a7246c4e-d3df-4f9d-81ff-f133eda68875"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a7246c4e-d3df-4f9d-81ff-f133eda68875" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Opportunities in Medicaid</em>, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), January 7, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Federal matches from Medicaid waivers and authorities, as well as grants from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Innovation Center (CMMI), are among the most commonly used federal-funding sources for state Medicaid agencies to support SDoH data and programming efforts to date (see sidebar “How California and North Carolina have harnessed waivers to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure”).</p>

<h3>2. Federal programs and agencies</h3>

<p>Federal programs and agencies encompass sources that regularly fund state Medicaid agencies and have supported SDoH and data and analytics infrastructure efforts, as well as sources that support SDoH efforts but are not commonly known for funding state Medicaid agencies (Exhibit 2).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/federal%20funding%20may%20boost%20social%20determinants%20of%20health%20infrastructure/svg_mck_shape_sdoh_funding_ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Many federal programs and agencies are available to support social determinants of health." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/federal%20funding%20may%20boost%20social%20determinants%20of%20health%20infrastructure/svg_mck_shape_sdoh_funding_ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p><em>Traditional state Medicaid support.</em> Traditional-funding sources that state Medicaid agencies can access come from both the CMMI and the Medicaid Enterprise System (MES) through the Center for Medicaid and CHIP Services (CMCS). CMMI provides grants to test modified payment approaches and, at times, offers specific grants to support SDoH initiatives. For example, CMMI’s past Accountable Health Communities Model grants linked Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries to community services with funding for screening social needs, referrals, and care navigation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1e9c35d1-acd3-4e62-9b14-95be0cbfe940"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1e9c35d1-acd3-4e62-9b14-95be0cbfe940" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Accountable health communities model,” CMS, last updated October 11, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Additional SDoH-related funding opportunities are likely to arise from CMMI given that it prioritizes health equity as a core strategic objective and addressing SDoH can help achieve this equity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d764b85c-ab24-4fdc-bc72-431efdc16899"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d764b85c-ab24-4fdc-bc72-431efdc16899" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Innovation center strategy refresh,” CMS, October 20, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>An in-depth look at CMCS MES funding</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Section 1903(a)(3) of the</strong> Social Security Act allows states to receive funding to modernize their IT systems and infrastructure to support Medicaid program management and administration needs, including managed care, clinical-decision support, and eligibility and enrollment. This funding is available to states to update and maintain IT systems to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the Medicaid program.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f05e41cf-f8ab-454f-8b01-42ba29afb368"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f05e41cf-f8ab-454f-8b01-42ba29afb368" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Health IT advisory council,” Connecticut Office of Health Strategy, July 25, 2021; “Mechanized claims processing and information retrieval systems-enhanced funding,” CMS, March 31, 2016; “Strategies for supporting and strengthening Medicaid information technology during the COVID-19 crisis,” State Health and Value Strategies, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Under this, states have the flexibility to define technology and data infrastructure needs and use cases if they are tied to program outcomes, thereby providing the potential to establish SDoH use cases and platforms, such as closed-loop referral systems, screenings, and resource directories.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e9f4bc83-e99d-443d-897a-a61e5d403b45"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e9f4bc83-e99d-443d-897a-a61e5d403b45" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Health IT advisory council,” Connecticut Office of Health Strategy, July 25, 2021; “Mechanized claims processing and information retrieval systems-enhanced funding,” CMS, March 31, 2016; “Strategies for supporting and strengthening Medicaid information technology during the COVID-19 crisis,” State Health and Value Strategies, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>States may receive a 90 percent federal match for design, development, and installation, and an ongoing 75 percent federal match for maintenance and operations activities. To access this funding, states must receive approval from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) by submitting advanced-planning documents (APDs). APDs may include a description of the state’s proposed use of the funding, the outcomes that are supported by the proposed infrastructure, demonstration of compliance with regulatory standards, and procurement and staffing plans.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0375bbad-cb62-4b91-8cf5-114f7df5d1c2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0375bbad-cb62-4b91-8cf5-114f7df5d1c2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Health IT advisory council,” Connecticut Office of Health Strategy, July 25, 2021; “Mechanized claims processing and information retrieval systems-enhanced funding,” CMS, March 31, 2016; “Strategies for supporting and strengthening Medicaid information technology during the COVID-19 crisis,” State Health and Value Strategies, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Under the proposed use of funding, when seeking a 75-25 percent match, states must have use cases certified by CMS as supporting the Medicaid Enterprise System (MES), demonstrating a value proposition specific to the Medicaid program with a clear statement of anticipated outcomes and key performance indicators for measurement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1556bbc5-18c9-4606-aacc-4e333602bae9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1556bbc5-18c9-4606-aacc-4e333602bae9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Health IT advisory council,” Connecticut Office of Health Strategy, July 25, 2021; “Mechanized claims processing and information retrieval systems-enhanced funding,” CMS, March 31, 2016; “Strategies for supporting and strengthening Medicaid information technology during the COVID-19 crisis,” State Health and Value Strategies, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, states must be diligent in cost allocation—considering opportunities to collaborate across multiple programs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3195999-f4cf-44ef-99c6-564887af3b7c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3195999-f4cf-44ef-99c6-564887af3b7c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Funding Medicaid health IT in the post-HITECH era,” Audacious Inquiry, March 9, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Overall, the APD process requires a deep understanding of Medicaid agency goals, current state technological and data capabilities and gaps, and how the two can come together for impact.</p>
<p>While this funding mechanism has not been widely used for SDoH-related efforts yet, the broad requirements of the program allow for states to consider pursuing SDoH data and infrastructure support. States such as Maryland are starting to tap into the opportunity. Maryland transitioned its health information exchange (HIE) from HITECH (Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health) funding to MES funding over a few years and is actively discussing SDoH data aggregation and other innovative use cases under their MES funding in partnership with HIE efforts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c4ffffab-306d-43dd-bb24-d608cc29bc29"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c4ffffab-306d-43dd-bb24-d608cc29bc29" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lindsey Ferris, “Rethinking conventional wisdom on Medicaid IT funding,” Healthcare IT News, January 31, 2022; “Funding Medicaid health IT in the post-HITECH era,” Audacious Inquiry, March 9, 2022; “596th meeting of the Health Services Cost Review Commission,” Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission, June 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> States may consider MES funding and HIE partnerships together to unlock greater support.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>CMCS MES approval, by comparison, is an ongoing funding source to advance Medicaid infrastructure and technology. CMCS MES funding is commonly used by states to build broader data and infrastructure but has to date been a largely untapped source for SDoH data and infrastructure capability-building (see sidebar “An in-depth look at CMCS MES funding”).</p>

<p><em>Funding from other government programs and agencies.</em> Other federal programs and agencies whose missions align with SDoH-related priorities, such as the Health Resources and Services Administration, Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Department of Agriculture, among others, present additional potential federal-funding sources. Stakeholders may be able to codevelop SDoH data and referral solutions by considering potential flexibility under block grants (that is, grants from a federal to local authority, often with flexibility for use) or through partnerships with other organizations that commonly receive funding from these sources—such as cities, counties, local public-health departments, and not-for-profits.</p>

<p>Others have set the precedent of using funding from these sources for SDoH-related technological support. For example, 211 San Diego is a not-for-profit organization connecting individuals with community, health, and disaster services. With a mix of corporate, foundation, and government resources—including US Department of Agriculture (USDA) resources supporting referral-related technology—it has developed a mobile application that gives users updates as they progress in the process of finding community services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="96844c9e-25bc-460b-aae6-258aefff4848"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="96844c9e-25bc-460b-aae6-258aefff4848" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Invest in our community,” 211 San Diego.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Other agencies, such as the CDC, have historically been less traditional sources for state Medicaid support but may present a greater opportunity going forward. Indeed, the CDC is forecasting an investment of roughly $4 billion through grants for strengthening US public-health infrastructure, workforce, and data systems that may be open to entities such as state and local governments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b32f17af-e07f-490e-a94f-4d537dc4f6cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b32f17af-e07f-490e-a94f-4d537dc4f6cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“OE22-2203 strengthening U.S. public health infrastructure, workforce, and data systems,” CDC, July 22, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>3. Recent legislation</h3>

<p>Recent laws such as the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) and the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law have increased the federal funding available to support SDoH-related efforts. This legislation is providing direct food and housing supports as well as investments in data modernization and infrastructure. For example, it was announced that funding from ARPA would also support the CDC’s public health infrastructure, workforce, and data modernization efforts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="077a55ba-40ce-4533-9332-1afccff09450"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="077a55ba-40ce-4533-9332-1afccff09450" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Strengthening U.S. public health infrastructure, workforce, and data systems,” CDC, last reviewed September 7, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Much of this funding will be seen through the federal programs and sources listed above, and SDoH stakeholders can watch for future grants and related opportunities from these new resources. An example of this is the inclusion of the Digital Equity Act in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which allocates $2.75 billion over five years to address, for example, broadband infrastructure to improve healthcare outcomes in underserved communities (Exhibit 3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="43d914a5-a4af-4892-9876-3b97b8f4f33e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="43d914a5-a4af-4892-9876-3b97b8f4f33e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yvette Scorse, “NDIA celebrates the Senate passage of the infrastructure bill,” National Digital Inclusion Alliance (NDIA), August 10, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>4. Managed-care standards and support</h3>
