class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>How Michigan used SIM funding and MCO requirements to advance SDoH infrastructure</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Michigan used</strong> State Innovation Model (SIM) funding and managed-care organization (MCO) requirements to advance SDoH data, analytics, and technology. The state received $70 million in SIM funding over four years to develop Community Health Innovation Regions, which built links between clinical and community resources.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa810b30-4784-45c9-9e38-407abaed2226"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa810b30-4784-45c9-9e38-407abaed2226" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Michigan’s State Innovation Model (SIM) initiative summary,” Michigan Department of Health and Human Services Policy, Planning and Legislative Services Administration, October 25, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> It required MCO contracts to participate in the SIM initiatives, increasing support for and coordination across SDoH efforts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1fed2f98-8f9e-4af0-91d3-ffd18e2bbfec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1fed2f98-8f9e-4af0-91d3-ffd18e2bbfec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Addressing social determinants of health via Medicaid managed care contracts and section 1115 demonstrations,” Association for Community Affiliated Plans, December 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The SIM-supported program focused on three components: population health, care delivery, and technology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b78f0e10-693a-4bf6-981a-612dd8acd63c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b78f0e10-693a-4bf6-981a-612dd8acd63c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Michigan’s State Innovation Model (SIM) initiative summary,” October 25, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The technology component focused on using statewide infrastructure and related health information exchange initiatives to enable and support advances in population health and care-delivery strategies, addressing SDoH.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="417807a2-9279-43d6-bb6c-094b78affe32"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="417807a2-9279-43d6-bb6c-094b78affe32" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Addressing social determinants,” October 2018; “Michigan’s State Innovation Model (SIM) initiative summary,” October 25, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The SIM technology team looked to develop a use case for the collection and reporting of SDoH data, identifying the data-sharing needs and requirements of Community Health Innovation Regions and community-based organizations (CBOs), and establishing standards for the data and technology platform for clinical-community linkages. SIM funding covered administrative needs, technical assistance, resource development, and workforce training to build capacity for care management and coordination, as well as data aggregation and analysis to support the creation and execution of program initiatives. The SIM grant officially ended in 2020, yet the state has looked to continue the work through initial state support and by disseminating the capability tools.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7a34d70e-2e9c-4b6b-beab-008003dd11a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7a34d70e-2e9c-4b6b-beab-008003dd11a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Addressing social determinants,” October 2018; “Michigan’s State Innovation Model (SIM) initiative summary,” October 25, 2018; “SIM initiative newsletter,” MDHHS State Innovation Model, January 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In addition, Michigan furthers SDoH efforts through its MCOs by requiring them to do the following<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="da496454-edff-4c80-8303-44f6ca108a62"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="da496454-edff-4c80-8303-44f6ca108a62" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Addressing social determinants,” October 2018.</span></span></span></a></span>:</p>

<ul>
<li>maintain a strategic plan to incorporate SDoH into data and analytics processes supporting population health</li>
<li>have Quality Assurance and Performance Improvement (QAPI) plans in place to analyze data, including SDoH, to understand variations in outcomes and utilization and develop system interventions to address drivers of disparate outcomes</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>There is potential to unlock funding for SDoH through standards and supports related to managed care (Exhibit 4). Managed care—a funding model through which payments are per patient rather than per service, with varying degrees of financial risk—is not itself a federal funding mechanism. But states can access federal support through federal grant initiatives related to managed care. For example, CMS alternative payment model innovation funding, such as past State Innovation Model (SIM) grants, are related to managed care (see sidebar “How Michigan used SIM funding and MCO requirements to advance SDoH infrastructure”). The SIM initiative provided federal support for states advancing multipayer healthcare payment and delivery system reform models to achieve better quality of care, improve care outcomes, and deliver lower costs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf27c2a6-3fdc-425c-9ca2-3f7a8a4983d2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf27c2a6-3fdc-425c-9ca2-3f7a8a4983d2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“State innovation models initiative: General information,” CMS, last updated September 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> States may continue to look for future CMMI grants focused on advancing managed care and innovative payment models to unlock SDoH data and potential infrastructure support.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/federal%20funding%20may%20boost%20social%20determinants%20of%20health%20infrastructure/svg_mck_shape_sdoh_funding_ex4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="States may be able to access federal support through federal-grant initiatives and federal standards related to managed care." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/federal%20funding%20may%20boost%20social%20determinants%20of%20health%20infrastructure/svg_mck_shape_sdoh_funding_ex4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Stakeholders can also take note of federal standards that can affect managed care, such as medical loss ratio (MLR) inclusion regulations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1b48bd3a-6ed7-45d4-9d92-32d8a92fe48a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1b48bd3a-6ed7-45d4-9d92-32d8a92fe48a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“§158.150 Activities that improve health care quality,” Code of Federal Regulations, September 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> MLR is a financial measurement defined by CMS that looks to demonstrate and ensure value for beneficiaries. This value is measured by quality improvement activities to improve healthcare outcomes, including wellness and SDoH.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dbefbdb4-c117-4b08-958e-6d9bd7535739"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dbefbdb4-c117-4b08-958e-6d9bd7535739" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Social determinants of health: Data sharing at the community level,” Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, March 2021; “§158.150 Activities,” September 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Linking SDoH investments to quality improvement may help states unlock additional support.</p>

<p>Beyond these federal supports, states have the flexibility to encourage innovation in SDoH across managed-care organizations (MCOs). For example, MCOs can use value-added services and “in lieu of” services to provide services that may include SDoH-related benefits; states may also use procurement, contracts, and performance management across MCOs to encourage SDoH-related innovations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7b0b8f11-c327-403e-8fdf-4f0153bd83ed"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7b0b8f11-c327-403e-8fdf-4f0153bd83ed" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CMS releases guidance on opportunities in Medicaid and CHIP to address SDoH,” Mercer, January 2021; “How are payment reforms addressing social determinants of health? Policy implications and next steps,” Milbank Memorial Fund, February 2021; “Maximizing federal investments to address SDoH,” Center for American Progress (CAP); <em>Opportunities in Medicaid & CHIP to address SDoH</em>, CMS, January 7, 2021; David Raths, “Medicaid managed care RFPs illuminate SDOH approaches,” Healthcare Innovation, January 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Data provides insight into who has unmet basic needs, and a referral platform can allow individuals to be connected to timely interventions that improve health outcomes.</p></blockquote></div>

<h2>Potential actions to advance SDoH infrastructure efforts</h2>

<p>Across funding mechanisms, states may consider eight actions to build on the current momentum around and increase emphasis on health equity and SDoH to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure efforts and potentially capture the full value of available funding channels.</p>

<p><em>Integrating SDoH into broader strategic priorities.</em> To unlock federal support for SDoH, states, vendors, payers, providers, and others are increasingly highlighting that SDoH is integral to broader strategic priorities across organizations rather than a one-off project. For the Medicaid program, for example, addressing SDoH could be part of the strategy to improve individual and population-level outcomes and to lower care delivery costs.</p>

<p><em>Articulating how SDoH data and infrastructure is a critical enabler.</em> In addition to integrating SDoH into broader strategic priorities, stakeholders may wish to emphasize the importance of SDoH data, technology, and infrastructure as an enabler to unlocking the value from SDoH. For example, data provides insight into who has unmet basic needs, and a referral platform can allow individuals to be connected to timely interventions that improve health outcomes. Emphasizing the role of SDoH data, technology, and infrastructure in enabling these efforts may support states and other stakeholders in accessing less-traditional funding mechanisms for this purpose.</p>

<p><em>Bridging the gap between IT or data programs and service-delivery programs.</em> To foster greater coordination and impact, IT and service delivery departments could work in tandem, recognizing the value SDoH data and technology can have in accelerating and improving service delivery efforts.</p>

<p><em>Partnering and combining funding mechanisms.</em> Stakeholders may consider combining or sequencing funding mechanisms—from multiple federal sources as well as state, local, private, and other sources—to potentially unlock greater resourcing and ensure sustainability. For example, if a state receives an 1115 waiver to advance SDoH data and technology, it may also pursue CMCS MES funding to advance the effort. To effectively streamline funding across partners, stakeholders may consider how to collaborate and work on joint efforts with a deliberate approach to cooperative governance. This partnership or coalition-based approach may unlock greater access to disparate funding mechanisms and ensure greater alignment across the SDoH ecosystem (Exhibit 5).</p>

<!-- -->

<p><em>Expanding target beneficiary populations.</em> Stakeholders could also consider steps to expand SDoH efforts to a variety of beneficiary populations, such as pregnant women and children, as SDoH data and technology enables a deeper understanding of needs and a greater reach with efforts. For example, closed-loop referrals can support a vast array of patients. This may also support states and other stakeholders in accessing less-traditional funding sources, such as from government agencies.</p>

<p><em>Evaluating governance and capability gaps.</em> Across funding sources, clear programming governance and a strong understanding of current state data and technology capabilities and gaps could be key to success in SDoH efforts.</p>

<p><em>Assessing approaches to implement SDoH infrastructure.</em> Stakeholders may consider approaches such as Medicaid contracting, MCO requirements and MLR allowances, health information exchange (HIE) partnerships, and department-specific initiatives to implement SDoH technology and infrastructure.</p>

<p><em>Considering how data is gathered and retained,</em> stakeholders may also want to consider what types of data and data collection and transmission standards are required to support SDoH in the context of interoperability. As conversations on interoperability continue, stakeholders will likely need discussions on data ownership, data systems of truth, and how the data is used in a way that optimizes and contextualizes care delivery and outcomes that drives holistic impact for an individual.</p>

<hr>

<p>Stakeholders across the broader healthcare ecosystem can come together and build on the momentum currently surrounding SDoH to potentially unlock transformational impact for patients and communities while also contributing to improved healthcare and economic productivity. Although numerous federal-funding possibilities are available in silos, a collaborative or partner-driven strategy—in which human services, Medicaid, and other stakeholders work together to use their relevant funding mechanisms to support the needs of their shared beneficiaries—could potentially boost the impact of SDoH efforts. This collaboration could encourage data sharing that may transform stakeholders’ understanding of unmet basic needs, including how to address them.</p>

<p>The authors wish to thank Erica Coe, Brian Latko, Meera Mani, Carlos Pardo Martin, and Sarah Miller for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Federal funding may boost social determinants of health infrastructure","displayName":"Federal funding may boost social determinants of health infrastructure","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"aa8b6630-8fe3-4adc-ba89-838f9696ee52","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Federal funding may boost social determinants of health infrastructure"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Social determinants of health infrastructure"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Federal-funding mechanisms represent an often-underused funding source for public- and private-sector stakeholders when enhancing SDoH data, analytics, and technology infrastructure."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Federal funding is an often-underused resource for enhancing social determinants of health (SDoH) data, analytics, and technology infrastructure."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-11-01T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSocial determinants of health (SDoH)\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026mdash;the conditions in which people live and the systems that shape those conditions\u0026mdash;are increasingly receiving attention. The COVID-19 pandemic, by exacerbating inequities and highlighting the prevalence of unmet basic needs,[[footnote 1]] has accelerated efforts to address SDoH.[[footnote 2]] State Medicaid agencies, payers, providers, vendors, community-based organizations (CBOs), and other stakeholders have taken up the torch and are laying the foundations for long-term SDoH programs (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;What are social determinants of health?\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the momentum, however, many stakeholders across the ecosystem are still in the early stages of addressing patients\u0026rsquo; SDoH sustainably and at scale. Stakeholders largely cite funding as the largest barrier to real progress.[[footnote 3]] Many stakeholders know of available funding for delivering services such as food assistance, housing support, and transportation. However, options for funding data, analytics, and technology infrastructure that can optimize efforts to deliver services are less well-known. But this funding does indeed exist. And it can be used to support data integration (collating social-needs data alongside clinical and other data) and screening and referral capabilities (business processes and capabilities that include SDoH data sets to drive enrollment into targeted case management profiles for patients\u0026rsquo; risk profile).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn pursuing these programs and seeking to secure funding, coordination across stakeholders may be crucial. SDoH is cut across a variety of focus areas and could be addressed better by working across payers, providers, states, communities, and other local actors and agencies. SDoH vendors can work alongside states and other entities to identify these funding possibilities and unify disparate stakeholders to unlock financial assistance, potentially resulting in evidence-based solutions across systems, clinical departments, and programs\u0026mdash;and, ultimately, increased impact (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Federal funding opportunities for actors that address social determinants of health\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThis article describes four federal financing mechanisms that are available to support SDoH data and analytics efforts and considerations for accessing them. While these insights primarily focus on possibilities for state Medicaid agencies, there are implications and potential opportunities for stakeholders across the ecosystem. This analysis is not exhaustive; rather, it provides a helpful starting point for planning and forming partnerships to support SDoH.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eFour federal-funding channels are available for SDoH infrastructure efforts\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 3]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eStakeholders can consider four federal-funding channels to advance their SDoH goals: waivers and authorities, federal agencies and programs, emerging opportunities resulting from recent legislation, and managed-care standards and support. Some of these federal channels provide ongoing support, for example, through a federal match or reimbursement strategy, while others provide one-time support such as through grants (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Definitions of funding terms\u0026rdquo;). Local- or state-level and private or philanthropic funding, while not evaluated in this article, may provide additional funding opportunities for stakeholders to consider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Waivers and authorities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough federal Medicaid funds are traditionally used to cover the costs of medical services, a variety of waivers and authorities have added flexibility so these funds can cover nonmedical services outside of the Medicaid state plan\u0026mdash;such as case management, food support, and housing support\u0026mdash;that contribute to health outcomes (Exhibit 1). This added flexibility may also cover data and analytics infrastructure to help improve how SDoH services are delivered and the outcomes of these services on people\u0026rsquo;s lives.[[footnote 4]] The Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) articulated a number of these waivers, authorities, and other supports available to address SDoH in a letter to state health officials in 2021.[[footnote 5]] More recently, the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC) released an issue brief on SDoH financing strategies.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n[[sidebar 4]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile waivers and authorities primarily fund direct-service delivery authorities, states often have flexibility in the proposals they put forth through waivers\u0026mdash;for example, they may define their own demonstration project or pilot for an 1115 waiver. But waivers also often include guidelines\u0026mdash;such as demanding budget neutrality or that a project demonstrates value in terms of quality and cost to the Medicaid program\u0026mdash;to ensure consistency in desired outcomes.[[footnote 7]] Federal matches from Medicaid waivers and authorities, as well as grants from the Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Innovation Center (CMMI), are among the most commonly used federal-funding sources for state Medicaid agencies to support SDoH data and programming efforts to date (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;How California and North Carolina have harnessed waivers to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Federal programs and agencies\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFederal programs and agencies encompass sources that regularly fund state Medicaid agencies and have supported SDoH and data and analytics infrastructure efforts, as well as sources that support SDoH efforts but are not commonly known for funding state Medicaid agencies (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTraditional state Medicaid support.\u003c/em\u003e Traditional-funding sources that state Medicaid agencies can access come from both the CMMI and the Medicaid Enterprise System (MES) through the Center for Medicaid and CHIP Services (CMCS). CMMI provides grants to test modified payment approaches and, at times, offers specific grants to support SDoH initiatives. For example, CMMI\u0026rsquo;s past Accountable Health Communities Model grants linked Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries to community services with funding for screening social needs, referrals, and care navigation.[[footnote 8]] Additional SDoH-related funding opportunities are likely to arise from CMMI given that it prioritizes health equity as a core strategic objective and addressing SDoH can help achieve this equity.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eCMCS MES approval, by comparison, is an ongoing funding source to advance Medicaid infrastructure and technology. CMCS MES funding is commonly used by states to build broader data and infrastructure but has to date been a largely untapped source for SDoH data and infrastructure capability-building (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;An in-depth look at CMCS MES funding\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFunding from other government programs and agencies.\u003c/em\u003e Other federal programs and agencies whose missions align with SDoH-related priorities, such as the Health Resources and Services Administration, Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Department of Agriculture, among others, present additional potential federal-funding sources. Stakeholders may be able to codevelop SDoH data and referral solutions by considering potential flexibility under block grants (that is, grants from a federal to local authority, often with flexibility for use) or through partnerships with other organizations that commonly receive funding from these sources\u0026mdash;such as cities, counties, local public-health departments, and not-for-profits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOthers have set the precedent of using funding from these sources for SDoH-related technological support. For example, 211 San Diego is a not-for-profit organization connecting individuals with community, health, and disaster services. With a mix of corporate, foundation, and government resources\u0026mdash;including US Department of Agriculture (USDA) resources supporting referral-related technology\u0026mdash;it has developed a mobile application that gives users updates as they progress in the process of finding community services.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOther agencies, such as the CDC, have historically been less traditional sources for state Medicaid support but may present a greater opportunity going forward. Indeed, the CDC is forecasting an investment of roughly $4 billion through grants for strengthening US public-health infrastructure, workforce, and data systems that may be open to entities such as state and local governments.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Recent legislation\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRecent laws such as the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) and the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law have increased the federal funding available to support SDoH-related efforts. This legislation is providing direct food and housing supports as well as investments in data modernization and infrastructure. For example, it was announced that funding from ARPA would also support the CDC\u0026rsquo;s public health infrastructure, workforce, and data modernization efforts.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMuch of this funding will be seen through the federal programs and sources listed above, and SDoH stakeholders can watch for future grants and related opportunities from these new resources. An example of this is the inclusion of the Digital Equity Act in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which allocates $2.75 billion over five years to address, for example, broadband infrastructure to improve healthcare outcomes in underserved communities (Exhibit 3).[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Managed-care standards and support\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 6]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThere is potential to unlock funding for SDoH through standards and supports related to managed care (Exhibit 4). Managed care\u0026mdash;a funding model through which payments are per patient rather than per service, with varying degrees of financial risk\u0026mdash;is not itself a federal funding mechanism. But states can access federal support through federal grant initiatives related to managed care. For example, CMS alternative payment model innovation funding, such as past State Innovation Model (SIM) grants, are related to managed care (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;How Michigan used SIM funding and MCO requirements to advance SDoH infrastructure\u0026rdquo;). The SIM initiative provided federal support for states advancing multipayer healthcare payment and delivery system reform models to achieve better quality of care, improve care outcomes, and deliver lower costs.[[footnote 14]] States may continue to look for future CMMI grants focused on advancing managed care and innovative payment models to unlock SDoH data and potential infrastructure support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eStakeholders can also take note of federal standards that can affect managed care, such as medical loss ratio (MLR) inclusion regulations.[[footnote 15]] MLR is a financial measurement defined by CMS that looks to demonstrate and ensure value for beneficiaries. This value is measured by quality improvement activities to improve healthcare outcomes, including wellness and SDoH.[[footnote 16]] Linking SDoH investments to quality improvement may help states unlock additional support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond these federal supports, states have the flexibility to encourage innovation in SDoH across managed-care organizations (MCOs). For example, MCOs can use value-added services and \u0026ldquo;in lieu of\u0026rdquo; services to provide services that may include SDoH-related benefits; states may also use procurement, contracts, and performance management across MCOs to encourage SDoH-related innovations.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003ePotential actions to advance SDoH infrastructure efforts\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAcross funding mechanisms, states may consider eight actions to build on the current momentum around and increase emphasis on health equity and SDoH to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure efforts and potentially capture the full value of available funding channels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntegrating SDoH into broader strategic priorities.\u003c/em\u003e To unlock federal support for SDoH, states, vendors, payers, providers, and others are increasingly highlighting that SDoH is integral to broader strategic priorities across organizations rather than a one-off project. For the Medicaid program, for example, addressing SDoH could be part of the strategy to improve individual and population-level outcomes and to lower care delivery costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eArticulating how SDoH data and infrastructure is a critical enabler.\u003c/em\u003e In addition to integrating SDoH into broader strategic priorities, stakeholders may wish to emphasize the importance of SDoH data, technology, and infrastructure as an enabler to unlocking the value from SDoH. For example, data provides insight into who has unmet basic needs, and a referral platform can allow individuals to be connected to timely interventions that improve health outcomes. Emphasizing the role of SDoH data, technology, and infrastructure in enabling these efforts may support states and other stakeholders in accessing less-traditional funding mechanisms for this purpose.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBridging the gap between IT or data programs and service-delivery programs.\u003c/em\u003e To foster greater coordination and impact, IT and service delivery departments could work in tandem, recognizing the value SDoH data and technology can have in accelerating and improving service delivery efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003ePartnering and combining funding mechanisms.\u003c/em\u003e Stakeholders may consider combining or sequencing funding mechanisms\u0026mdash;from multiple federal sources as well as state, local, private, and other sources\u0026mdash;to potentially unlock greater resourcing and ensure sustainability. For example, if a state receives an 1115 waiver to advance SDoH data and technology, it may also pursue CMCS MES funding to advance the effort. To effectively streamline funding across partners, stakeholders may consider how to collaborate and work on joint efforts with a deliberate approach to cooperative governance. This partnership or coalition-based approach may unlock greater access to disparate funding mechanisms and ensure greater alignment across the SDoH ecosystem (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[ceros 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExpanding target beneficiary populations.\u003c/em\u003e Stakeholders could also consider steps to expand SDoH efforts to a variety of beneficiary populations, such as pregnant women and children, as SDoH data and technology enables a deeper understanding of needs and a greater reach with efforts. For example, closed-loop referrals can support a vast array of patients. This may also support states and other stakeholders in accessing less-traditional funding sources, such as from government agencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvaluating governance and capability gaps.\u003c/em\u003e Across funding sources, clear programming governance and a strong understanding of current state data and technology capabilities and gaps could be key to success in SDoH efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAssessing approaches to implement SDoH infrastructure.\u003c/em\u003e Stakeholders may consider approaches such as Medicaid contracting, MCO requirements and MLR allowances, health information exchange (HIE) partnerships, and department-specific initiatives to implement SDoH technology and infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsidering how data is gathered and retained,\u003c/em\u003e stakeholders may also want to consider what types of data and data collection and transmission standards are required to support SDoH in the context of interoperability. As conversations on interoperability continue, stakeholders will likely need discussions on data ownership, data systems of truth, and how the data is used in a way that optimizes and contextualizes care delivery and outcomes that drives holistic impact for an individual.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eStakeholders across the broader healthcare ecosystem can come together and build on the momentum currently surrounding SDoH to potentially unlock transformational impact for patients and communities while also contributing to improved healthcare and economic productivity. Although numerous federal-funding possibilities are available in silos, a collaborative or partner-driven strategy\u0026mdash;in which human services, Medicaid, and other stakeholders work together to use their relevant funding mechanisms to support the needs of their shared beneficiaries\u0026mdash;could potentially boost the impact of SDoH efforts. This collaboration could encourage data sharing that may transform stakeholders\u0026rsquo; understanding of unmet basic needs, including how to address them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLegal disclaimer:\u003c/strong\u003e These materials do not constitute legal, medical, policy, or other regulated advice. current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis paper uses\u003c/strong\u003e two phrases throughout: \u0026ldquo;unmet basic needs\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;social determinants of health\u0026rdquo; (SDoH). We define unmet basic needs as the lack of a basic resource such as food, safe housing, or transportation. An unmet basic need may or may not have an adverse effect on a person\u0026rsquo;s health. SDoH is used to refer to the nonmedical factors that influence health outcomes.[[footnote 1]] The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines SDoH as the conditions in the environments where people are born, live, learn, work, play, and age that affect a wide range of health risks and outcomes. Examples include education access and quality, neighborhoods and built environments, and economic stability.[[footnote 2]] Studies indicate that approximately 20 percent of an individual\u0026rsquo;s health is related to clinical care. Nonclinical factors, including SDoH, are responsible for the remaining 80 percent.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAcross the healthcare industry, stakeholders are increasingly recognizing that addressing SDoH, which reflect unmet basic needs, can lead to improved health outcomes and better quality and costs of care.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOther common terms include \u0026ldquo;social risk factors\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;social influencers of health.\u0026rdquo; Language is increasingly evolving to recognize that social factors are influences on (rather than determinants of) health and well-being.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What are social determinants of health?"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Social determinants of health,\u0026rdquo; World Health Organization (WHO).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Social determinants of health,\u0026rdquo; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), last reviewed March 29, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e2020 county health rankings key findings report\u003c/em\u003e, Country Health Ranking \u0026amp; Roadmaps, March 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Review of evidence for health-related social needs interventions,\u0026rdquo; The Commonwealth Fund, July 2019; \u0026ldquo;Addressing social determinants of health: Examples of successful evidence-based strategies and current federal efforts,\u0026rdquo; Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, April 1, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eState Medicaid agencies:\u003c/strong\u003e These agencies support the administration and operation of the Medicaid program in their states and determine coverage for social determinants of health (SDoH) support. They also develop the data and infrastructure necessary to identify and address people\u0026rsquo;s SDoH-related needs. These agencies are primary recipients of federal funding through mechanisms such as waivers and authorities. They can also partner with vendors, community partners, or providers to access new funding and allocate acquired capital\u0026mdash;for example, using funding from a Section 1115 waiver to partner on closed-loop referrals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSDoH vendors:\u003c/strong\u003e Vendors are typically private organizations that contract with other actors to support SDoH service delivery or data and infrastructure. They can receive funding indirectly through partnerships and contracting, such as through work with state Medicaid agencies, managed-care organizations, or state health information exchanges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePayers:\u003c/strong\u003e These organizations cover members\u0026rsquo; medical costs and can work alongside providers to ensure members\u0026rsquo; health needs (including SDoH-related needs) are met. Funding can come through subcontracts with states on provision of services to beneficiaries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eProviders:\u003c/strong\u003e Providers consist of physicians and other practitioners who provide direct care to patients, screen for unmet basic needs, provide referrals to support, and at times offer direct-service provisions (for example, a hospital offering food support). Federal funding can come indirectly through partnerships and subcontracting, such as risk-based payment models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCommunity-based organizations (CBOs):\u003c/strong\u003e These not-for-profit organizations primarily provide relief to the community\u0026mdash;for example, through food banks and housing organizations. They can provide direct services for individuals with SDoH-related needs and may also support other actors with local knowledge and credibility. They may receive federal funding indirectly through grant programs, or they can receive additional funding through partnerships such as a managed-care organization referral partnership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOther state and local agencies:\u003c/strong\u003e These departments and agencies include counties, cities, behavioral-health facilities, and aging organizations. They help allocate resources to CBOs and other entities to address unmet basic needs. These groups are primary recipients of federal funding for select financing mechanisms, such as grants from national entities such as the CDC and through recent legislation such as the American Rescue Plan Act, which provided $350 billion to state, local, and other entities.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Federal funding opportunities for actors that address social determinants of health"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Assistance for state, local, and tribal governments,\u0026rdquo; US Department of the Treasury.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFederal match:\u003c/strong\u003e A federal match is the share the federal government will contribute to a project based on the nonfederal share of costs the grantee is contributing to the effort. In Medicaid, there are two common types of federal matches:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFederal Medical-Assistance Percentage (FMAP).\u003c/em\u003e For every dollar the state spends on Medicaid, the federal government matches at a rate that varies from year to year. FMAP is the portion paid by the federal government to states for their share of expenditures for providing Medicaid services as well as administering the Medicaid program and other human service programs. It is computed from a formula that considers the average per capita income for each state relative to the national average.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFederal Financial Participation (FFP).\u003c/em\u003e FFP is the share of each state\u0026rsquo;s Medicaid administrative costs paid by the federal government (that is, matching funds for states\u0026rsquo; systems and data infrastructure expenditures, often at an enhanced match rate of 75 to 90 percent).[[footnote 2]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMedicaid waivers and authorities:\u003c/strong\u003e Under a Medicaid waiver or authority, a state can waive certain Medicaid eligibility requirements and expand offered services, covering care for people who might not otherwise be eligible (for example, waiving Section 1115 of Title XIX of the Social Security Act).[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMedical loss ratio (MLR):\u003c/strong\u003e An MLR is the proportion of a premium a health plan spends on healthcare claims and quality improvement activities compared with administrative activities.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Definitions of funding terms"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Medicaid\u0026rsquo;s federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP),\u0026rdquo; Congressional Research Service, July 29, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Federal match rates for Medicaid administrative activities,\u0026rdquo; Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission (MACPAC).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Waivers,\u0026rdquo; MACPAC.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Social determinants of health: Data sharing at the community level,\u0026rdquo; Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, March 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCalifornia and North Carolina\u003c/strong\u003e provide examples of how states can harness waivers in combination with other funding sources (federal and otherwise) to advance social determinants of health (SDoH) service delivery and data and technology infrastructure across their Medicaid programs and beyond.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eCalifornia is working to transform its Medicaid program (known as Medi-Cal) into a whole-person approach through the California Advancing and Innovating Medi-Cal (CalAIM) effort. The California Department of Health Care Services launched CalAIM in January 2022 to improve health outcomes and health equity across the state.[[footnote 1]] CalAIM envisions enhanced information exchange, coordination, and data integration across managed-care plans; county agencies; and physical-health, behavioral-health, community-based, and social-service providers.[[footnote 2]] The effort is supported by state funding in addition to several federal authorities, including 1115 and 1915(b) waivers, state plan amendments, and managed-care contracts.[[footnote 3]] The 1115 waiver is particularly relevant for SDoH technology, providing $1.4 billion over five years for an initiative aimed at capacity building, technical assistance, and other efforts, including closed-loop referrals.[[footnote 4]] To advance closed-loops referrals, CalAIM provides guidance for information sharing, standards to ensure platforms are accessible to contracted providers, and training and technical assistance to support providers in workflow changes and access.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eNorth Carolina, meanwhile, is advancing on multiple SDoH-related fronts[[footnote 6]]:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNCCARE360.\u003c/em\u003e North Carolina developed NCCARE360, a statewide coordinated-care network to better connect individuals to local services and resources.[[footnote 7]] The NCCARE360 network uses a statewide closed-loop referral platform adopted by state agencies, health systems, community-based organizations (CBOs), and managed-care organizations (MCOs). It began with a public\u0026ndash;private partnership between the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (NC DHHS), a foundation, an SDoH technology vendor, and United Way (a not-for-profit driving 211 resource directories).[[footnote 8]] Initial funding for the network came through the combination of private philanthropy and a Medicaid federal match. NCCARE360 has been expanded and continued by requiring and covering access for Medicaid MCOs and health systems to use the platform for an initial period.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHealthy Opportunities Pilots.\u003c/em\u003e Alongside NCCARE360, North Carolina has been driving SDoH impact through its Healthy Opportunities Pilots.[[footnote 10]] The pilots aim to both address unmet basic needs for members and build capacity for entities delivering social services, including connecting Medicaid members to reimbursable social-care services, streamlining eligibility and authorization processes, enabling CBOs to automatically invoice for services, and providing data to evaluate outcomes.[[footnote 11]] As a part of this effort, North Carolina has created standard screening questions for unmet basic needs and encourages providers to use NCCARE360.[[footnote 12]] The pilots started through an 1115 waiver that was approved as part of the state\u0026rsquo;s waiver to transition to Medicaid managed care.[[footnote 13]] Through the waiver, Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) granted $650 million in funding over five years, $100 million of which can be used for capacity building with a 50-50 federal match.[[footnote 14]] In this transition, North Carolina is advancing SDoH in four ways: having SDoH-related contract requirements, supporting CBOs delivering Healthy Opportunities Pilots\u0026rsquo; services, allowing plans to include SDoH service and infrastructure in the numerator of their medical loss ratios (MLRs), and requiring plans to participate in pilots.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBoth the North Carolina and California case studies demonstrate how states have used waivers alongside other sources to advance their SDoH technology efforts. While North Carolina has approached SDoH technology and closed-loop referral development through a single, state-supported network and platform, California is taking a different approach: supporting data-sharing standards and technical assistance across groups rather than through a single platform or network. These cases reflect the flexibility in how states could use waivers, third-party vendors, and other funding to develop and support SDoH infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How California and North Carolina have harnessed waivers to advance SDoH data and technology infrastructure"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;CalAIM explained: Overview of new programs and key changes,\u0026rdquo; February 3, 2022; \u0026ldquo;North Carolina Medicaid transformation: Healthy opportunities in Medicaid managed care,\u0026rdquo; Piedmont Triad Regional Council, June 27, 2019.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"5"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSection 1903(a)(3) of the\u003c/strong\u003e Social Security Act allows states to receive funding to modernize their IT systems and infrastructure to support Medicaid program management and administration needs, including managed care, clinical-decision support, and eligibility and enrollment. This funding is available to states to update and maintain IT systems to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the Medicaid program.[[footnote 1]] Under this, states have the flexibility to define technology and data infrastructure needs and use cases if they are tied to program outcomes, thereby providing the potential to establish SDoH use cases and platforms, such as closed-loop referral systems, screenings, and resource directories.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStates may receive a 90 percent federal match for design, development, and installation, and an ongoing 75 percent federal match for maintenance and operations activities. To access this funding, states must receive approval from the Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid Services (CMS) by submitting advanced-planning documents (APDs). APDs may include a description of the state\u0026rsquo;s proposed use of the funding, the outcomes that are supported by the proposed infrastructure, demonstration of compliance with regulatory standards, and procurement and staffing plans.[[footnote 3]] Under the proposed use of funding, when seeking a 75-25 percent match, states must have use cases certified by CMS as supporting the Medicaid Enterprise System (MES), demonstrating a value proposition specific to the Medicaid program with a clear statement of anticipated outcomes and key performance indicators for measurement.[[footnote 4]] In addition, states must be diligent in cost allocation\u0026mdash;considering opportunities to collaborate across multiple programs.[[footnote 5]] Overall, the APD process requires a deep understanding of Medicaid agency goals, current state technological and data capabilities and gaps, and how the two can come together for impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile this funding mechanism has not been widely used for SDoH-related efforts yet, the broad requirements of the program allow for states to consider pursuing SDoH data and infrastructure support. States such as Maryland are starting to tap into the opportunity. Maryland transitioned its health information exchange (HIE) from HITECH (Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health) funding to MES funding over a few years and is actively discussing SDoH data aggregation and other innovative use cases under their MES funding in partnership with HIE efforts.[[footnote 6]] States may consider MES funding and HIE partnerships together to unlock greater support.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"An in-depth look at CMCS MES funding"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Health IT advisory council,\u0026rdquo; The state received $70 million in SIM funding over four years to develop Community Health Innovation Regions, which built links between clinical and community resources.[[footnote 1]] It required MCO contracts to participate in the SIM initiatives, increasing support for and coordination across SDoH efforts.[[footnote 2]] The SIM-supported program focused on three components: population health, care delivery, and technology.[[footnote 3]] The technology component focused on using statewide infrastructure and related health information exchange initiatives to enable and support advances in population health and care-delivery strategies, addressing SDoH.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe SIM technology team looked to develop a use case for the collection and reporting of SDoH data, identifying the data-sharing needs and requirements of Community Health Innovation Regions and community-based organizations (CBOs), and establishing standards for the data and technology platform for clinical-community linkages. SIM funding covered administrative needs, technical assistance, resource development, and workforce training to build capacity for care management and coordination, as well as data aggregation and analysis to support the creation and execution of program initiatives. The SIM grant officially ended in 2020, yet the state has looked to continue the work through initial state support and by disseminating the capability tools.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, Michigan furthers SDoH efforts through its MCOs by requiring them to do the following[[footnote 6]]:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003emaintain a strategic plan to incorporate SDoH into data and analytics processes supporting population health\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ehave Quality Assurance and Performance Improvement (QAPI) plans in place to analyze data, including SDoH, to understand variations in outcomes and utilization and develop system interventions to address
